Metadata.siteDescription: Borough-by-borough performance grades for Montreal, powered by the city's own open data. Permits, 311 requests, snow removal, and more.

HomePage.heroSubtitle: MontréalScore connects campaign promises to real outcomes — tracking permit delays, contract spending, and political commitments using the City's own open data. No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the numbers.
HomePage.volunteerBody: The contracts page tracks billions in municipal spending, but verifying sole-source justifications, finding related news coverage, and cross-referencing supplier data takes time. The promise tracker also needs help — monitoring council decisions, flagging progress on commitments, and sourcing updates from local media. If you're a journalist, researcher, data analyst, or engaged citizen — we'd love your help.
HomePage.ctaTitle: No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the data.
HomePage.ctaBody: All data comes from the City of Montreal's open data portal and public reporting. Updated regularly. MontréalScore connects promises to outcomes — so you can hold your government accountable.

metadata.title: Construction Permits — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking construction permit processing times by borough in Montreal.

PermitsPage.title: Housing Permits
PermitsPage.subtitle: Processing times for housing permits (projects adding dwelling units) vs the {target}-day target (Mayor Martinez Ferrada's promise). The previous target was {previousTarget} days.
PermitsPage.housingNote: Housing permits = projects adding dwelling units (nb_logements > 0). The 90-day target applies to these permits. Tree cutting, pool, fence, and snow permits are excluded.
PermitsPage.noHousingData: No housing permit data available for this year. Try selecting a previous year.
PermitsPage.chartFootnote: Green dashed line = {target}-day target. Colors reflect the borough's grade. Housing permits only (projects adding dwelling units).
PermitsPage.methodologyText: This page shows housing permits only — projects that add dwelling units (nb_logements > 0 in the dataset). The 90-day processing target applies to these residential projects, not to tree cutting, pool, fence, or snow permits. Processing times are calculated from the date_debut (application date) and date_emission (issuance date) fields. The median is used instead of the average to reduce the impact of outliers. Data is updated weekly by the City.

metadata.title: About — MontréalScore
metadata.description: How MontréalScore works, what it tracks, and how you can contribute.

AboutPage.title: About MontréalScore
AboutPage.intro: MontréalScore is a free, open-source accountability tool that tracks the performance of Montreal's municipal government using the City's own open data and public reporting.
AboutPage.intro2: We track campaign promises, construction permit processing times, and municipal contract spending — giving Montrealers a clear, fact-based picture of how their city is being run.
AboutPage.whatPromisesDetail: Every major campaign commitment made by Mayor Soraya Martinez Ferrada and Ensemble Montréal, tracked from announcement to delivery. Each promise is rated (completed, in progress, partially met, or broken) with sourced updates from local news coverage.
AboutPage.whatPermitsDetail: Borough-by-borough analysis of permit processing times. The mayor promised a 90-day turnaround — we track how each borough actually performs, with median wait times and year-over-year trends.
AboutPage.whatContractsDetail: Every city contract over $2,000 — who gets them, how much they're worth, and whether spending patterns raise questions. Includes procurement threshold analysis and supplier concentration data.
AboutPage.whyBody: Politicians make promises. Open data exists. But no one was connecting the two. The median permit processing time exceeds 200 days in some boroughs despite a 90-day target. Campaign commitments are announced at press conferences and then forgotten. Contract data is published but never analyzed in context.
AboutPage.whyBody2: MontréalScore connects the dots. No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the data, the sources, and the results.
AboutPage.dataSourcesIntro: All quantitative data comes from <link>Montreal's open data portal</link>. Promise tracking uses public news reporting. Datasets include:
AboutPage.dataPromisesDetail: manually tracked with sourced updates from La Presse, Le Devoir, CBC, Journal Métro, and city publications
AboutPage.methodologyIntro: For permits, each borough receives a grade from A to F based on a composite score considering:
AboutPage.methodologyMedian: Median processing time vs the 90-day target (40%)
AboutPage.methodologyPct: Percentage of permits processed on time (40%)
AboutPage.methodologyPromises: For promises, each commitment is rated based on publicly verifiable evidence: official announcements, budget documents, news coverage, and city data. Statuses are updated as new information becomes available.
AboutPage.contributeBody: MontréalScore is only as good as its sources. If you have information about a campaign promise, a news article we missed, or a correction — we want to hear from you.
AboutPage.contributeTip: Spotted progress (or broken promises) that we haven't tracked yet?
AboutPage.contributeSource: Have a news article, council meeting clip, or budget document to share?
AboutPage.contributeCorrection: Found an error in our data or analysis?
AboutPage.contributeHow: Send tips and corrections to <email>me@ashwater.ca</email>. All submissions are verified before publication.
AboutPage.contactBody: MontréalScore is built by <brule>Brulé AI</brule>, an independent Montreal-based studio. For inquiries, tips, or media requests: <email>me@ashwater.ca</email>.

metadata.title: Municipal Contracts — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking municipal contracts for the City of Montreal — suppliers, departments, and amounts.

ContractsPage.title: Municipal Contracts
ContractsPage.subtitle: Procurement contracts approved by city council, executive committee, borough councils, and civil servants. Intergovernmental transfers are excluded.
ContractsPage.concentrationSubtitle: What share of municipal spending goes to the largest suppliers?
ContractsPage.concentrationDetail: of spending goes to the top {count} suppliers
ContractsPage.distributionSubtitle: Number of contracts by value range. Highlighted bars border Quebec procurement thresholds.
ContractsPage.distributionFootnote: Highlighted bars = ranges adjacent to $25K (no formal process) and $139K (mandatory public tender, 2026-2027 threshold) thresholds.
ContractsPage.thresholdSubtitle: In Quebec, contracts under $25K require no formal process. Above the public tender threshold, a public call for tenders is mandatory. The threshold has changed over time ($100K in 2017, $101.1K in 2019, $105.7K in 2022, $121.2K in late 2022, $133.8K in 2024, $139K in 2026). The analysis below applies the threshold in effect at each contract's approval date.
ContractsPage.thresholdMethodology: Comparison uses a symmetric value band above the threshold as baseline. The threshold applied matches the one in effect at each contract's approval date. A ratio significantly above 1 may indicate contract splitting. Sources: <lcv>art. 573.3.1.2, Loi sur les cités et villes</lcv> ($25K threshold); <mamh>MAMH — Conformité des contrats municipaux</mamh> (public tender thresholds, adjusted biennially via Muni-Express).
ContractsPage.soleSourceSubtitle: Contracts awarded without competitive bidding, as identified in council/committee descriptions. Sole-source contracts are legal under Quebec law for specific situations (urgency, sole supplier, security) but their growth is a key transparency indicator.
ContractsPage.soleSourceNone: No sole-source contracts identified in this period. Sole-source awards are identified from council/committee decision descriptions, which are not available for contracts under delegated authority (civil servants).
ContractsPage.yearlyTrendSubtitle: How contract spending breaks down by which body approves: civil servants (delegated authority, under $25K–$139K), borough councils, executive committee, city council, or agglomeration council. Larger contracts require higher-level approval.
ContractsPage.notableFindingsSubtitle: Patterns and outliers in the contract data that warrant further investigation. These are observations, not accusations — each may have a legitimate explanation.
ContractsPage.findingProanimaBody: In November 2023, city council awarded a 10-year sole-source contract (gré à gré) worth $158M to Proanima Montréal, a non-profit, for city-wide animal management services. This is the 4th largest single contract in the dataset and the 2nd largest sole-source award. As the only provider of these services on the island, the sole-source justification is legally valid — but the scale raises questions about oversight and value for money.
ContractsPage.findingSoleSourceGrowthTitle: Sole-source spending grew 8.6x in a decade
ContractsPage.findingSoleSourceGrowthBody: Sole-source contract value went from $48M in 2015 to $414M in 2025. While some of this reflects larger infrastructure projects with legitimate sole-supplier justifications, the trend significantly outpaces inflation and overall budget growth.
ContractsPage.findingDurokingBody: The city's datasets record Duroking Construction under 14 different spellings (with/without Quebec Inc number, different punctuation, different separators). Without normalization, this major supplier appears fragmented across the top-supplier rankings — understating its true market share. We identified and merged similar patterns for 30+ suppliers.
ContractsPage.findingSingleBidderBody: Beyond sole-source contracts, some publicly tendered contracts attracted only a single bidder (soumissionnaire unique). From 2015–2025, 319 such contracts totalled $480M. While the process is formally competitive, a single bidder means no price competition occurred.
ContractsPage.normalizationSubtitle: The city's five contract datasets contain thousands of supplier name variants — typos, casing differences, trailing punctuation, and Quebec Inc numbers appended in different formats. Without normalization, the same company appears as multiple entries, understating true concentration.
ContractsPage.normalizationExplanation: We maintain a curated list of known variants for the largest suppliers. Names that don't match a known variant are standardized by normalizing casing and stripping trailing commas. Below are examples of the mergings applied.
ContractsPage.methodologyText: Data comes from five City of Montreal open datasets: contracts approved by city council, the agglomeration council, the executive committee, and borough councils, plus contracts awarded under delegated authority by civil servants. Intergovernmental transfers (ARTM, STM, CMM, etc.) and union/pension contributions are excluded to focus on actual procurement. Supplier names are normalized to merge known variants (e.g. 14 spellings of "Duroking Construction"). Sole-source contracts are identified by text matching "gré à gré" in council/committee decision descriptions — some records may contain the phrase in a sub-clause rather than as the primary award type. Amounts are in Canadian dollars.
